clinical_study.brief_title: Non-invasive Haemodynamic Monitoring to Predict Spinal Hypotension During Caesarian Section
clinical_study.official_title: Can Non-invasive Haemodynamic Monitoring With Clearsight(r) Predict Spinal Hypotension During Caesarian Section? A Prospective Observational Study

brief_summary.textblock:
Spinal anaesthesia for elective caesarean section is associated with maternal hypotension, secondary to alteration of sympathetic tone and hypovolemia, in up to 70% of cases.
Our objective, in this prospective single-centre observational study, was to assess the ability of change in systolic ejection volume after 45Â° passive leg raising to predict hypotension after spinal anaesthesia. Systolic ejection volum was monitored with non-invasive Clearsight Device just before elective caesarean section in third trimester pregnant women.

primary_outcome.description: Systolic ejection volume is measured using Clearsight (non invasive monitoring device)

secondary_outcome.description: Velocity - Time - Integral is measured using transthoracic cardiac ultrasound

clinical_study.condition: Spinal Anesthetics Causing Adverse Effects in Therapeutic Use

arm_group.arm_group_label: Third trimester pregnant women undergoing ceasarean section

intervention.description: Non invasive hemodynamic monitoring using a finger cuff Cardiac ultrasound performed to calculate Velocity - Time - integral (VTI) Both intervention are performed before and after a passive leg raising challenge.
intervention.arm_group_label: Third trimester pregnant women undergoing ceasarean section

study_pop.textblock: prospective inclusion of 3 rd trimester pregnant women undergoing spinal anesthesia for elective ceasarean section

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- third trimester pregnant women undergoing elective ceasarean section under spinal anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- emergent ceasarean section
- eclampsia or pre-eclampsia
- undergoing anti-hypertensive treatment
- arythmia
